description: Consider problem of placing N queens on an n X n board so that each queen attacks precisely k others. Here k=4 and sequence gives number of different solutions when N takes its maximal value.
comments: I would also like to get the sequences that give the maximal value of N.An answer to this comment: I would also like to get the sequences that give the maximal value of N. What is the maximum number of queens that can be placed on an n*n chessboard such that no two attack one another? The answer is n queens, which gives eight queens for the usual 8*8 board (Madachy 1979; Steinhaus 1999, p. 29). The number of different ways the n queens can be placed on an n*n chessboard so that no two queens may attack each other for the first few n are 1, 0, 0, 2, 10, 4, 40, 92, ... [From Claudio (lordofchaos000(AT)hotmail.com), May 31 2010]
references: M. Gardner, The Colossal Book of Mathematics, 2001, p. 209.
links: Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Queens Problem [From Claudio (lordofchaos000(AT)hotmail.com), May 31 2010]
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Oct 03 2002
extensions: I am not certain this description is correct, nor how rigorous the results are.
